dt: {bc}the same or nearly the same (as in appearance, character, or quantity)

dt.t: it behoved him to be made {wi}like{/wi} unto his brethren
the importance of statistics as the one discipline {wi}like{/wi} to give accuracy of mind

et: Middle English, alteration of {it}ilich{/it}, from Old English {it}gelīc{/it} like, alike, from {it}ge-{/it}, associative prefix + {it}līc{/it} body; akin to Old High German {it}gilīh{/it} like, alike, Lithuanian {it}lygus{/it} like {ma}{mat|co-|}{/ma}
shortdef: the same or nearly the same (as in appearance, character, or quantity) —formerly used with as, unto, of
closely resembling the subject or original

dt.t: you'll try it, some day, {wi}like{/wi} enough

dt: used interjectionally in informal speech often to emphasize a word or phrase (as in "He was, like, gorgeous") or for an apologetic, vague, or unassertive effect (as in "I need to, like, borrow some money")

dt.t: the actual interest is more {wi}like{/wi} 18 percent

dt: used interjectionally in informal speech with expressions of measurement
